head.title: Packing Asia Into a Menu and Taking It All Downtown

hedline.hl1: Packing Asia Into a Menu and Taking It All Downtown

abstract.p: Eric Asimov, in $25 and Under column, reviews Daily Chow, Asian restaurant on Lower East Side (M)

block.p: WALKING the narrow line between culinary authenticity and popular appeal, Brad Kelley has always managed to keep his balance. His restaurants, Kin Khao, Kelley & Ping, and Bop, each present an Asian cuisine in a seductive downtown environment, where unfamiliar foods are wrapped in a cushion of cocktails, sexy design or creature comforts. While he has won over young American crowds, the tradeoff has been toned-down food.

His latest restaurant, Daily Chow, which opened just a few weeks ago, brings the Thai dishes of Kin Khao and Kelley & Ping and the Korean dishes of Bop together with Chinese, Japanese and Vietnamese preparations. Such variety would seem almost impossible for any one restaurant to master: it's the equivalent of specializing in European foods from Spain to Russia. But Daily Chow does enough things well and is so good-natured that a meal there can be thoroughly enjoyable.

WALKING the narrow line between culinary authenticity and popular appeal, Brad Kelley has always managed to keep his balance. His restaurants, Kin Khao, Kelley & Ping, and Bop, each present an Asian cuisine in a seductive downtown environment, where unfamiliar foods are wrapped in a cushion of cocktails, sexy design or creature comforts. While he has won over young American crowds, the tradeoff has been toned-down food.

His latest restaurant, Daily Chow, which opened just a few weeks ago, brings the Thai dishes of Kin Khao and Kelley & Ping and the Korean dishes of Bop together with Chinese, Japanese and Vietnamese preparations. Such variety would seem almost impossible for any one restaurant to master: it's the equivalent of specializing in European foods from Spain to Russia. But Daily Chow does enough things well and is so good-natured that a meal there can be thoroughly enjoyable.

The spare two-level design manages to be simple and good-looking. The walls are painted in warm colors, while a sense of Asia is conveyed quietly through bamboo light fixtures and a tall light sculpture joining the two floors that looks like a luminous abacus. The bar and smoking area are on the darker second floor; the ground level is quieter.

The centerpiece on the ground floor is a sort of salad bar used for the so-called Mongolian barbecue section of the menu. You fill a bowl with vegetables and noodles, select shrimp, chicken or beef and a sauce ($8.50), and hand it to a cook for stir-frying. The result is a prefabricated dish with little flavor that is far easier to imagine at a health-food restaurant than in Mongolia.

Preferable alternatives include Chinese scallion pancakes ($5.75), crisp and savory, served with a soy dipping sauce, and Chinese shrimp with salt-and-pepper crust ($7.50), so delicate you can eat the briny shell. Two Thai soups ($4.50), tom yum gung with shrimp and lemon grass, and gai tom kha with chicken and coconut milk, are excellent, while a Japanese soy broth with soba noodles and tempura ($8.95) is simultaneously delicate and hearty.

But Daily Chow falls short with wrapped and stuffed dishes, whether Chinese shrimp dumplings ($5.95) or Vietnamese ravioli ($5.50) and summer rolls ($5.95). Flavors are insipid, the wrappings thick and clumsy.

The food can certainly seem secondary. Daily Chow focuses on a drinking crowd, offering pitchers of cocktails ($30) with names like ginger kamikaze and Thai dye that seem to invite oblivion, though there is a small but well-chosen list of wines ($28 to $35 a bottle).

Of the main courses, the Korean dishes are most successful. Bulgogi ($12.95), tender, flavorful shreds of beef, comes with spicy kimchi, while bibimbop ($14.95), the famous rice, beef and egg dish, is served with vegetables in a hot stone crock so that the bottom layer turns crisp. Pork chops ($14.25) are thin as blades, Vietnamese style, delicious in their marinade of soy, cilantro and lemon grass.

But some of the Thai dishes are marred by a lack of spicing. Nua kaprow ($12.95), sauteed beef with onions and basil, for example, is a delightful blend, with the anise flavor of the basil amplifying the flavor of the beef, but it needs at least a nudge of chili to bring it all together. Similarly, gung gratiem ($14.50), shrimp sauteed with garlic and onions, lacks a spicy dimension. Dishes where spicing isn't expected, like beef massaman curry ($12.95), which is often slightly sweet from coconut milk and tamarind juice, fare better.

One of my favorite dishes is a dessert, mango sticky rice ($5.50), sweetened with coconut milk and served with mango slices; it is surprisingly authentic. A ginger-flavored brownie with coconut ice cream is about as Asian as a Big Mac, but delicious nonetheless.
With Daily Chow, the winning atmosphere and enough good dishes help to make tolerable the timid spicing. Mr. Kelley is still walking that fine line, and he hasn't fallen yet.

2 East Second Street, at Bowery, East Village; (212) 254-7887. BEST DISHES: Scallion pancakes, salt-and-pepper shrimp, Thai soups, bulgogi, bibimbop, Vietnamese pork chops, beef massaman curry, mango sticky rice, ginger brownie. PRICE RANGE: Appetizers, $3 to $8.95; main courses, $7.95 to $14.95. CREDIT CARDS: All major cards. HOURS: Daily, noon to midnight. WHEELCHAIR ACCESS: Ramp at entrance; restroom on ground floor.
